title: How to know if you find your true self - Quora

response.answer_text: Q. How do you know when you have truly discovered your true self? (1) You know yourself, and have a view of yourself. This is View ‘A’. (2) Others know you. You’ve a view of what others think of you. This is View ‘B’. (3) Others’ actual view of you. This is View ‘C’. (4) We come back to the Quora question: How do you know when you have truly discovered your true self? Answer: When you find that the above A = B = C.Complete consonance of you, and your relationship to the world. Metaphysical unity bliss.But, it’s not definitive truth. Because you can’t ever be sure what others really think of you, even if they tell you candidly, sincerely, honestly. What they think of you plays out in their minds. You’ve no access to their minds.You have a higher probability of the tri-congruency if you live in a society that gives primacy to the collective. Communitarianism.Conversely, you have zero probability of the tri-congruency if you live in a society that rah rah celebrates the soaring Individual. You’re a perpetual work-in-progress in this society because of enforced individualism.That said, you can truly know yourself if you live in complete isolation. You’re defined by View A, period. But then again, there may be no self for you to know. Your self is defined in relation to others, as a mountain is defined by its valley.(5) Related: Sam Qwato's answer to Why do most people have an average life? How does one have a higher life?

Try being silent for a day or at least part of your day, observe your surroundings and pay attention to your thoughts, since what you think or how you think determines who you are as a person. During this period, think about what makes you happy and what makes you sad, what inspires you, and what discourages you. (Note: It would be more beneficial to write the question and answer down to later reflect on) Also, think about your flaws, for example, if you're prone to anger or say things you don’t mean, think about what kind of people you have allowed in your life, since your friends reflect who you are, ask yourself what do you hate and what do you like, and who do you think you are or wish to be.

Unlimited creativity: you sense that you could just make it up all day long. No longer bound by fixed beliefs about your identity, the floodgates open and you sense that you’re channeling an infinite possibility generator.Genuine responsiveness to life: you’re moved by stuff — things that happen to others, the pain of others, the joy of others. You’re flowing on a river that includes you and everything else, and it has an emotional depth and richness that you cannot express in language.A profound sense of responsibility: you recognize that this is very much your world to save, you stop thinking that it’s “out there” like something you can ignore, and realize that it’s “in here” with you, in a container that’s vast and open-ended. A prison cell that you share with the world and cannot ignore.Peace that isn’t withdrawal. Before, you could only be at peace if you isolated yourself from sources of upset. But true self can be at peace in the midst of chaos.Tolerance for uncertainty: you’re no longer bothered by not knowing what’s next. Your ability to dance with the music means that you don’t freak out about tripping over you feet sometimes when things change unexpectedly.I can go on. The point is that the “bar” for this is a lot higher than most people think. Complacency is not appropriate, in light of that.

It is a paradox. What is True Self. Just like the questions, Why was am I in this world, What am I supposed to do with this life? These questions are questions which you cannot answer because the closer you go to it, the further you get from it. You’re using your mind to identify your true self. Like a sword that cuts, but cannot cut itself. Like an eye that can see, but cannot see itself. Like the mind identifies, but cannot identify itself. Being Buddha is finding your true self. This being is free from any world attachment. This does not mean that he has no feeling, emotions or sense of pains. It is just is. Don’t think of it as a spirituality context where you are thinking about God when you are peeling potatoes. You are just peeling the potatoes. When it’s time to get dressed, put on your cloths. When you must walk, then walk. When you must sit, then sit. Don’t have a single thought in your mind about seeking your true self. Because you are already it. You may have doubts and such that you are not from all the experiences but just let the sky is always blue. Clouds will change the colours to grey and block the view. But no matter what blocks it, the sky will always be blue. I talk more about this topic in this video.

Oh goodness. So many ways this question could be answered, but how much justice can words really do? I’m not sure your temperment or tendencies, but if you’re into contemplation, listening, learning, transformation, reflecting, being open to change, I’d recommend checking out Adyashanti’s writing and lectures. There are others like him, too. Eckhart Tolle is very accessible. If you find their talks on YouTube, you might be led to others’, too. If you’re into meditation, first of all, realize that lots of meditation practices are not aimed at better self-awareness or gnosis or… the idea of knowing the self means different things in different traditions. But, if possible find a Vedic self-inquiry meditation teacher who is familiar with and appreciates Ramana Maharshi. In general, explore the internet with the term “Self-Inquiry”. You might find some interesting things. These are some recommendations. :) Edit: Since this question was (originally) phrased, “How do YOU find YOURself?” Well, for me… I am not entirely sure. I’m not even sure there’s a self to find. But the things I mentioned, and more, and things I explore. On another level of “self”, I also take stock and check in al the time (repeatedly throughout each day or even hour) with how much I am enjoying ot not enjoying a given tsk or thought or choice or experience. When I follow wisdom, i make these choices consciously, in a way that is love and joy oriented. I do not alwys make these wise choices - I will tell you that. Following through on joy and love is a way of showing my “self” or my heart in a way that feels… like making the most of this life. But on another level, I seem to be very gradually letting go of how important everything is… all my thoughts and feelings on things (and thoughts and feelings are ultimately our perception of everything after all right? We percieve through our eyes and minds). So I can take life less seriously. But you know. These are just words. Nobody really knows what’s going on :-P

Hi, Its very simple. You are doing painting using water color, its your choice. But, doing math is something that’s thrust upon you, either by your parents/school or society. Anything you do at your own will, own interest, and when and if you derive happiness from it, we can call it being your true self. At the end of the day it all boils down to a very primitive, simple fact. Doing what you love, your calling, your dream. Whatever you enjoy doing is the true self you are looking for. Anything that you love doing, should be your job, and it should surprise you because, someone is paying you to do that. Any epiphanies? ;) I guess that’s all I have to say. Good luck discovering your true self and be happy always.. Cheers..! PS : If you revel in doing something, enjoy it to the core, then you are already there. True self is what you have found. Meet that person and never let go. :)

There is no answer to this question. We do not know, yet, what consciousness is. Therefore we do not know what the self is. Anyone who says, “I have found myself,” has found something other than any evidence for what consciousness or the sense of self actually is. However, you will find no shortage of people telling you how to find it, and how they found it. Only, they will be telling different stories. My answer? What you see is what you get. Take a close look at your life. What you are thinking and what you are doing. You are the sum of those two things. Where you want to go from there will take some imagination, but it’s up to you.

When you feel satisfied That is how you know. There are no preset conditions to how you must be. How your personality becomes is entirely up to you. Take time to learn about how you wish to become in order to determine what is best to you. What is good when it comes to the personality is relative. Instead of worrying about it just be the way you want to be.

We find the God within. “Paradigm Busters, Reveal the Real You”, at Amazon, gives the steps to achieve this.
